node.text: If you’ve dreamed of voyaging out to meet our ocean’s extraordinary wildlife but don’t even know where to begin, this is your chance! The deadline to enter for the opportunity to win a sailing adventure with @PaulNicklen and I is August 19, 2021. Even if you have no experience with being on the ocean and sailing, Paul and I will be with you every step of the way to make sure you have the time of your life. All you need is a love for the sea. We’ll teach you the secrets of photographing marine animals and enjoy snorkeling in tropical waters — all while restoring and protecting our ocean. Every dollar we raise from this contest goes directly into marine conservation through supporting @SeaLegacy. Click the link in my bio to ENTER or go to omaze.com/oceans to learn more. We cannot wait to meet you! #Omaze @Omaze

node.text:
After decades of allowing our planet to burn for corporate interests, it’s long past time we stop standing in the way of the people who are trying to save this world. On this year’s Day of the World’s Indigenous Peoples, join @NiaTero with @AmplifierArt in supporting Indigenous leaders by amplifying “THRIVING PEOPLES. THRIVING PLACES.” campaign. Click the link in my bio or visit www.niatero.org/thrivingpeoples to meet the Indigenous women leading the world into a just and thriving future. 

Art by @tracieching @cindychischilly featuring @GuajajaraSonia, @Celia.Xakriaba, @NaraSoaress, @PaniaNewton, @Kunaq, Vicky Tauli, Gunn-Britt Retter, Deb Abrahamson, and Twa-le Abrahamson. 

#ThrivingPeoplesThrivingPlaces #IndigenousPeoplesDay #WorldIndigenousPeoplesDay

node.text:
Visit @ecologyst_ to learn more // Film by @gogoandthebandit @mommehalbe and @cammacarthur. Featuring @tjwatt @ola_randellini @drsuzannesimard. 

Slicing down a living giant that is hundreds, perhaps thousands of years old, and turning it into decking or roofing is not worth the price of an ancient ecosystem. Click the link in my bio to sign the petition to protect Fairy Creek and take a stand for British Columbia’s last remaining Old Growth Forests. Then tag a friend below to do the same. Old-growth forests take centuries to become the finely tuned systems we see today. They support vast networks of biodiversity in ways scientists are only just starting to understand. These are forests that we will never be able to replicate. Once it’s cut, it’s gone. So speak out, share this far and wide, and write our local policymakers to demand a moratorium on logging Canada’s ancient primary forests. Together we can protect the last of our forests’ true Titans. 
@fairycreekblockade @ancientforestalliance

node.text: 🔈 Please turn your volume up to meet Shaba, the first matriarch of the Reteti Elephant Sanctuary @r.e.s.c.u.e, in this deeply moving film by my good friend @AmiVitale. Shaba’s shining spirit and resilience in the wake of tragedy is the medicine this world needs now more than ever. Click the link in my bio or visit shabafilm.org to watch her story on-demand until August 31st. All proceeds from the tickets go directly to supporting Shaba’s community of rescued elephants and the dedicated keepers who are working to rehabilitate them back to the wild. The sanctuary is Indigenous-owned and run by the Samburu community- the first initiative of its kind. Please give them a follow and share this video far and wide.  @sararafoundation @conservationorg @kenyawildlifeservice @nrt_kenya @tusk_org @sandiegozoo @thephotosociety @passionplanet #shabafilm #shaba #retetielephants  #DontLetThemDisappear #elephants #saveelephants #stoppoaching #kenya #natureisspeaking #conservation

node.text:
There is a reason why we taste salt in our tears when we cry. It’s a reminder that when the ocean dies, so do we. The sea gives us food, medicine and keeps our climate in balance. It is the birthplace of life itself, and if we are not careful with its gifts, we will lose everything. Video by @sheltondupreez 

My life began far from the shore in Mexico. But even as a little girl, I could hear that rising call from the tides begging to be answered. I would pour over books on the sea and marvel at the strange creatures looking back at me from the pages. Some of us fear what lies beneath the surface, forgetting that we too once called the ocean home- long before our ancestors crawled on land. I, however, have always been enthralled by it. The second I had the chance to explore its briny depths, I jumped straight in and never looked back. Images shot on my @SonyXperia 1III.  @SonyXperiaUS #SonyXperia #Xperia1III #TakenWithXperia.

node.text:
One thing that blew my mind when I first moved to Vancouver Island was the fact that old-growth rainforest used to cover the entire landmass and because of industrial logging, today, 90% is gone.  Gone!  Old trees play a critical role in boosting the immunity of a forest. When we cut them down, we lose the blueprint of an entire ecosystem’s resilience. Across Canada, we’ve learned the hard way a forest is not just a grove of trees. We cannot level what took hundreds, sometimes thousands, of years for nature to perfect and expect it all to come back. Click the link in my bio to urge our government officials to protect Fairy Creek and the last of British Columbia’s old growth forests, before it is too late. @fairycreekblockade 

Video by @ReelWater

node.text:
Of all the places I have visited in the ocean, Timor-Leste’s reefs and tropical waters were some of the most spectacular wonders I have ever seen. Please turn your volume up for this behind-the-scenes-look into Timor-Leste’s incredible marine biodiversity and experience for yourself the most surprising animal encounter that changed all of our lives 🐋 The communities of Timor-Leste have depended on and cared for their seas for generations. Through the traditional use of marine resource management, this ocean nation is establishing itself as a world leader in marine conservation, responsible ecotourism, and locally-managed fishing. All you have to do to see the effects of these culturally-rooted practices is peek beneath the surface and you’ll find reefs overflowing with colorful schools of fish, coral, anemones, and even blue whales- the largest animal in the history of Earth. Join us @sealegacy and @onlyone by becoming part of #TheTide and help support places like Timor-Leste through our mission to create community-based action for our ocean. 

On expedition for @sealegacy in Timor-Leste with @PaulNicklen, @andy_mann, and @sonyalpha. #ShotOnSony #SonyAlpha #BeAlpha

node.text:
The story of our ocean is one of triumph, heartbreak, and life in its most spectacular forms- but it is far from complete. There are gaps in the narrative and there has never been a more crucial time to come together as storytellers to shine a light on the challenges our planet faces. Across the world, marginalized communities struggle to survive on the edge of a dwindling sea. Entire species are quietly disappearing along with vast stretches of coral reefs and seagrass beds. This is where I am drawn to as a photographer and marine conservationist; the silences, the empty spaces. It’s why @PaulNicklen and I set sail on the @SeaLegacy 1 and work every day to shine a light on our ocean’s greatest threats and bring the solutions that can change the world to life. Thank you @SonyAlpha for making our work possible. And thank you to my dearest friend and diving partner @Andy_Mann for directing this masterpiece. #SonyAlpha 

Director / Editor: @Andy_Mann
EP: @Mparns @CurtisMorgan
DP: @SamKretch
AC: @Kyle.Roepke

node.text:
For decades, the Galápagos marine reserve protected a vital ecosystem so diverse, it forever changed our very understanding of life on Earth. But the iconic park is no longer enough. Since the day it was established, our world population has more than doubled and our seas are depleting faster than at any point in human history. As beautiful and rich as the preserve is, it cannot help restore our ocean and support local economies if its borders are flanked and breached by an army of fishing fleets from faraway shores. Join us in calling on President Lenín Moreno @leninmorenog and President of the National Assembly @cesarlitardo to expand the world heritage site and meet the new challenges of a rapidly changing climate head on. We are on the brink of a new decade in conservation, one that will ultimately define the fate of all marine life. Sign and share the petition linked in my bio and urge Ecuador’s government to lead us all into a sustainable future. @mas_galapagos2020 @sealegacy @onlyone 
Thanks to @luksth and @dvfernandez for lending your voices
.
.
@mission_blue @migramarnet

node.text: If there’s one thing I’ve learned as a conservationist and artist, it’s to never underestimate the power of storytelling. As one of the oldest forms of communication for human beings, stories can be a powerful means to rally each other to action. This Thursday, join us in celebrating the ocean heroes who are changing hearts and sparking movements through their photography and visual storytelling at the virtual Ocean Photography Awards Show. The show will be streaming on the new Ocean Photography Awards YouTube channel starting at 2pm ET (11am PT). Click the link in my bio to access the awards. I want to thank our participants for submitting some of the most evoking work I’ve seen in photography. Your images and powerful stories have given me such hope for our planet. This will be the decade that defines the future of marine conservation and it all starts with you and your passion for our ocean. I can’t wait for this Thursday! #oceanstory #oceanphotography

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier on September 08, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: Imagine what kind of world we could have if we allow every corner of our ocean to thrive like the waters of the Galápagos. Building resilience in our planet’s marine ecosystems is one of the best defenses against a destabilized climate and global defaunation. Click the link in my bio to help @OnlyOne and @sealegacy expand protections in the Eastern Tropical Pacific Seascape (ETPS) and create abundant seas for generations to come. With the first day of Autumn just around the corner, it’s almost time to get back to chasing the stories and amplifying the solutions that will help shape the course of our ocean’s future. I’m grateful for the time I’ve been able to work from home, but I’m also looking forward to getting back on the SeaLegacy 1 and back to creating images in our planet’s wildest seascapes.

node.text:
@IAmAliTabrizi, director of @SeaSpiracy, ecologist and writer @CSafina, and I are teaming up this Thursday September 9th and we want you to join us. Click the link in my bio to RSVP to our digital #TalkAboutDriftnets event starting at 7pm ET. 

Driftnets are currently decimating ocean wildlife along the coasts of the United States. These massive death traps are used to catch animals like swordfish, but drown and entangle countless species of marine life including sea turtles. For every one swordfish caught, seven other animals die with it. It’s time to ban this archaic and completely unnecessary practice in federal waters once and for all. Join us this Thursday to learn more and take a stand for our ocean. #BANdriftnets

Photo by Cristina Mittermeier on September 06, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: I live where the salmon rivers feed into forests of towering cedars and firs. My back porch opens out to a view of the sea framed by distant mountain ridges. Beneath the rolling blanket of the surface lies a colorful seascape of curiosities patrolled by sea lions and orcas. Diving along the coasts brings me back to the days I spent pouring over books on marine life as a child in Mexico. I would study the illustrations of iridescent moon jellies, brightly colored anemones, and creatures that looked like they were plucked from an alien world. I couldn’t have known that I would someday see those exact animals through a camera’s lens or that I would move to these rugged coasts. Yet somehow, even then, I think part of me knew this was home.

node.text: “Murmuration in Waves” / An explosion of life swarmed the reef of the Galapagos as schools of fish crowded around me. I peered through the cloud of flashing scales, rising and ebbing like a flock of starlings, and spotted the source of their panic. A lone silhouette slipped into sight and I could make out the unmistakable shape of a hammerhead. It stalked slowly along the edge of the shoals, stirring them into a flurry. During the day, massive groups of hammerheads like this congregate just off the reefs. They break away from each other only at night to hunt the open seas. The abundance of sharks and massive schools of fish are a sign that the ecosystem is functioning as it should be. Every species has its part to play in the drama of ocean life. Click the link in my bio to inquire about pricing on this print and learn more of the stories behind each of my fine art pieces. #hammerhead #fineartphotography #fineartprint

node.text: Despite all my time documenting the orca pods of Norway and British Columbia, these clever cetaceans have a wonderful habit of surprising me with every encounter. I caught this group spy-hopping to get a good peek at our boat. They rose high above the surface and studied us before sinking quickly back into the dark waters. Orcas share complex conversations with one another over vast distances, orchestrating hunts and keeping each other informed on their surroundings. I had no doubt this group was chatting about us underwater. Community is everything to the orca, a trait we share. As this pod hunted the shoals of herring below, a group of activists, scientists, and my team were coordinating our own movement to keep their hunting grounds free from oil drilling. Thanks to the tireless efforts of our ocean community, we succeeded.

node.text: Fine Art print “Weightless” / We came across this iceberg floating like a blue-glass asteroid in space. It looked impossibly fragile and yet somehow immovable, fastened to the mirror surface of the sea and already melting beneath the Arctic sun. Our planet’s polar kingdoms seem eternal, but over the years, cartographers have had to redraw the shrinking ice caps over and over again. Earth is not the same place it was even 10 years ago. I wanted to preserve this beautiful sculpture in one of the most delicate stages in its cycle and to remind us all the time to act on climate change is now. Click the link in my bio to inquire for pricing on this print and learn more about my fine art.

node.text: As someone who has dived among Antarctica’s ice floes and experienced Russia’s polar North, I can honestly say there is nothing on this planet that could prepare you for winter in Northern Greenland. Sled dogs like this, on the other hand, are made to roam the Arctic wilds. While I was bundled up to my eyes in more layers than I could count, the dogs didn’t seem to mind the howling winds and snow. But even these intrepid canines need the support and command of their mushers to ensure their survival. In turn, the Inuit hunters who make their home in this hostile climate depend on the seasonal formation of sea ice and the cooperation of their sled dogs to feed their families. The story of Greenland is the story of the ancient alliance between people and dogs. This way of life, and the stability of the northern hemisphere is at risk, however. This summer Greenland’s ice sheet summit experienced rain for the first time in history. It’s time to act on climate.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier on September 01, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text: The Bahamas is known for its white-sand beaches, turquoise surf, and sunsets that drench the islands in warm pink hues. But it’s the secret world of mangroves, coral reefs, and endless seagrass meadows that captivate me the most. These habitats are so vibrant and beautiful they’ve kept me submerged with my camera for hours, twisting the arm of dusk to get that last shot of the day. They’re also critical for mitigating the damage caused by powerful storms. Today marks the 2nd anniversary of Dorian’s landfall in Abaco and Grand Bahama. Recovery and rebuilding efforts are still ongoing, even two years later. With record-setting hurricanes like Dorian and the more recent Hurricane Ida becoming the norm, it is more crucial than ever to revitalize our planet’s natural defense systems.

node.text: Through my lens, I watched this mom-and-daughter ballet unfold beneath the Caribbean sun in Domica. The pair twirled in perfect synchronicity while I silently cheered them on from the sidelines. Sperm whales are incredibly playful with enormous personalities to match their size. Females average about 30,000 pounds, whereas males can reach a whopping 90,000 pounds — which makes for an impressive splash when they breach! This particular calf is affectionately known as “Ariel.” She’s won over the hearts of photographers and marine biologists alike with her bold and curious nature. It was such a treat to spend the day with her and her beautiful family. It’s moments like this that drive me to fight harder to restore our ocean and protect the extraordinary animals we share it with.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier on August 30, 2021. May be a closeup of bird.

node.text: What I wouldn’t give to see the world through the eyes of the albatross. These beautiful birds have a wingspan up to 11 ft (~ 3 m) and command the currents of formidable storm systems with uncanny grace. In the early 2000s, a single grey-headed albatross was tracked by GPS at a sustained speed of 75 mph for 9 hours while casually riding the tailwind of a powerful Antarctic storm. Even more impressive was how he continued to forage along the surface with little effort, despite the chaos unfurling around him. I cannot imagine what it must be like to have such mastery over the skies. Looking through my lens at this particular bird resting along the rocky cliffs, I could only guess at the wonders he must have seen throughout his lifetime. #albatross #albatros

node.text: “Strike a Pose” / Peering through the lens of my camera, I could see the soft hair on this bear’s nose was damp from snuffling through the snow. She prowled the frozen surface, her claws fastening her to the ice like giant hooks. After a moment, she paused and lifted her snout to the wind, the softest smile tugging at the corners of her mouth. I love creating images that showcase both the power and personalities of animals like polar bears. It takes an incredible amount of tenacity and heart to thrive in the wilds of the Arctic. This image is from my most recent fine art collection, “Regeneration,” and is available for purchase as an archival pigment print. Click the link in my bio for more details and to inquire about pricing. #fineart #fineartphotography #polarbear

node.text: Thank you all so much for joining me yesterday for the opening of “Origins!” It was a joy to spend the evening in the company of such an engaging group of people. I picked up a camera as a young marine scientist to answer the call of a planet in crisis. The images I’ve made over the years serve as both a reminder of the natural beauty in this world and a glimpse into what our future could be if we learn to take care of it. “Origins” is a journey through each of the pivotal moments @PaulNicklen and I have experienced that ultimately gave rise to @SeaLegacy, @OnlyOne, and our mission to help our seas flourish once more. The gallery will remain open until October 2nd, so please feel free to stop by if you’re in the area! Click the link in my bio for more information.
